text.p: Swedish appliance maker Electrolux on Tuesday posted a 14 percent fall in earnings for the first quarter and promised no relief in its depressed traditional markets.

The company posted a profit of 777 million crowns ($99.6 million) after one-time items for the first three months of the year compared to the same 1996 period. It said sales rose 4 percent to 28.72 million crowns ($3.68 million).

"So far this year we have faced a very difficult market situation in Europe, with lower demand in almost all product areas," said Electrolux Managing Director Leif Johansson in a written copy of his exit speech.
Johansson, who is leaving Electrolux to take over at Swedish vehicle maker AB Volvo, said the European white goods, or heavy household appliances, market shrank 3 percent in the first quarter.
"The North American market has, however, been more stable but with a slight fall in demand for white goods compared with the first quarter of last year," he added.
Johansson will be replaced by Michael Treschow, who had been chief executive of industrial engineering company Atlas Copco and is known in markets as a cost-cutter with a focus on shareholder value.
Average market expectations put the first quarter profit after financial items at 910 million crowns ($116 million).
The news sent the stock tumbling 16 crowns ($2.05), or 3.4 percent, to 457 crowns ($58.56), but it recovered a little later in the day.
The company said it would focus on improving logistics and marketing in order to make the operation less fragmented.
Both the U.S. and European white goods markets, which make up the backbone of the company's sales, have contracted, it said.
The company also said lower sales volumes and a less favourable product mix hurt the group's European operations.
